title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to recognize the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and a distinct Indian community. The State of North Carolina has recognized the Lumbee Indians as an Indian tribe since 1885. The Lumbee Indians have been recognized by the State of North Carolina since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, but have not received full federal recognition and benefits. Congress now acknowledges the Lumbee Indians as an Indian tribe and supports their entitlement to full federal recognition and associated privileges. The Lumbee Tribe is seeking full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe to receive benefits, privileges, and immunities. The Lumbee Tribe is seeking full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe to receive benefits, privileges, and immunities. SEC. 3. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, applying all laws and regulations of general application to Indians and Indian tribes to the tribe and its members. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, including members in specific counties, can seek federal acknowledgment of tribal existence. Members are eligible for services and benefits as a federally recognized tribe, with some residing near an Indian reservation. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, residing in specific counties, can seek federal acknowledgment of tribal existence. Upon verification of a tribal roll, the Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for services eligible to tribe members. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can request federal acknowledgment of tribal existence. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will use the verified tribal roll to define the tribe's service population for budgeting federal services. The verification process must comply with the tribe's constitution adopted on November 11, 2000, and be completed within one year of the enactment of this section. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's constitution, adopted on November 11, 2000, requires verification of tribal existence within one year of enactment. Fee lands to be conveyed to the United States must be treated as trust acquisitions if located in Robeson County. North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands within the tribe's territory. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina's constitution requires verification of tribal existence within one year. North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe or any dependent Indian community. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States. The Lumbee Tribe may transfer jurisdiction from North Carolina to the United States through an agreement, with a 2-year waiting period. This transfer does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to implement this Act.
